prompt: Mark told Pete many lies about himself, which Pete included in his book. He should have been more skeptical.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Mark".   In this sentence, "He" is a pronoun that takes the place of a noun. Since the subject of the sentence is "Mark", "He" is used to refer to Mark in the subordinate clause "He should have been more skeptical." This is an example of a pronoun referring back to a noun in the previous clause for clarity and brevity.

prompt: The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them. They are very happy to have them back, but they scold them just the same because they ran away.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "mothers"? Explain your choice.
response: In the given sentence, "them" refers to "Arthur and Celeste."   This is because the sentence structure is a subject-verb-object (SVO) pattern, with "the mothers" as the subject performing the action of fetching, "Arthur and Celeste" as the object being fetched, and "them" as a pronoun replacing "Arthur and Celeste" in the second part of the sentence. This is an example of an object pronoun, which is used to refer to a noun or a group of nouns previously mentioned.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain, promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mr. Singer"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "He" refers to "Mark".   The reason for this is that the sentence is structured as: "Mark was close to Mr. Singer's heels... He heard him calling for the captain..."   Here, "Mark" is the subject of the first clause ("Mark was close to Mr. Singer's heels"), and "he" is a pronoun referring back to the subject of the first clause, which is "Mark". The sentence then continues with "him", which refers to "Mr. Singer", indicating that Mr. Singer is the one doing the calling.

prompt: The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice; but at last he just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge. He wanted me to help him out, but I hope you will excuse me, sir, I did not feel inclined to do so.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "young gentleman"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "He" refers to the pony.   This is because the sentence is structured as follows:   - "The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice;" (subject: the pony) - "and at last he just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge." (Here, "he" is a pronoun that refers back to the subject of the previous clause, which is the pony. The pony is the one performing the action of throwing up its heels and tipping the young gentleman into the thorn hedge.)  This use of "he" is an example of anaphora, where a pronoun is used to refer back to a previously mentioned subject.

prompt: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "the cup"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "it" refers to "the cup." This is an example of a pronoun reference, specifically an anaphoric pronoun. The pronoun "it" is used to refer back to a previously mentioned noun, in this case, "the cup." This type of pronoun reference is called an anaphora.  The reasoning behind this is based on the context of the sentence. Since the action of pouring water is being performed onto the cup, and the cup is the recipient of the action, it is logical to assume that "it" refers to the cup.

prompt: Dan had to stop Bill from toying with the injured bird. He is very compassionate.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Dan"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Dan". The sentence structure suggests that Dan is the subject performing the action of stopping Bill from toying with the injured bird. The pronoun "He" is used to refer back to Dan, indicating that Dan is the one who took the action.

prompt: Sam Goodman 's biography of the Spartan general Xenophanes conveys a vivid sense of the difficulties he faced in his childhood.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Goodman"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Goodman." The pronoun "he" refers to "Xenophanes."   In the sentence, "Sam Goodman" is the subject performing an action (conveying a sense), and "Xenophanes" is the subject being described, specifically in his childhood.

prompt: Pam's parents came home and found her having sex with her boyfriend, Paul. They were furious about it.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "Pam's parents"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "They" refers to Pam's parents. This is because the pronoun "They" is used as the subject of the verb "were" in the phrase "They were furious about it." The subject of a sentence is typically the noun or pronoun that performs the action described by the verb. In this case, Pam's parents are the ones who are performing the action of being furious, so "They" must refer to them.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education, but now Charlie acts as though it never happened. He is very hurt.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Bob".   The subject of the sentence is "Bob", and "He" is a pronoun used as a subject pronoun to refer back to the subject of the sentence.

prompt: Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share his toy.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Toby"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "his" refers to "Toby."   The reason is that "his" is a possessive pronoun, indicating that the toy belongs to Toby. In the sentence, "Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share his toy," "his" is used to show that the toy is Toby's possession, so it is referring back to Toby as the owner of the toy.

prompt: Emma did not pass the ball to Janie although she was open.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Janie"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Emma did not pass the ball to Janie although she was open," "she" refers to "Janie."   This is because "she" is used as a pronoun to replace the subject "Janie" in the subordinate clause "although she was open." The sentence structure is:  - Emma (subject of the main clause) did not pass the ball to Janie. - Although (subordinating conjunction introducing the subordinate clause) she (referring to Janie) was open (predicate of the subordinate clause).  In this context, "she" is a pronoun used to refer back to Janie, indicating that Janie was the one who was open.

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one below it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "it" is likely referring to "Sam's drawing".   The reason for this is that the sentence mentions "Sam's drawing" and then describes an improvement to it by adding another drawing below it. The pronoun "it" is used to refer back to the subject of the sentence, which is "Sam's drawing".   The use of "it" creates a clear connection between the initial subject (Sam's drawing) and the action being described (looking better with another drawing below it).

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education, but now Charlie acts as though it never happened. He is very ungrateful.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Bob". This is because the pronoun "He" is used as a subject pronoun, referring back to the subject of the sentence, which is "Bob". In this context, "He" is a third-person singular pronoun that replaces the subject "Bob" to avoid repetition and improve sentence flow.

prompt: The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to answer it.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the lawyer"? Explain your choice.
response: In the given sentence, "he" refers to the witness.   This is because the sentence structure is in the form of "SVO" (Subject-Verb-Object), where "the witness" is the subject, "asked" is the verb, and "the lawyer" is the object. In this context, the pronoun "he" is a subject pronoun, and it refers back to the subject, which is "the witness".

prompt: Sam took French classes from Adam , because he was eager to speak it fluently.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Sam"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "Sam".   This is because the subject-verb agreement rule is being applied. In the sentence, the subject "Sam" is a singular noun, and the verb "took" is in the third person singular form, agreeing with the subject "Sam". The pronoun "he" is also a third person singular pronoun, which matches the verb "took" in number and person, making it grammatically correct to refer to "Sam" with the pronoun "he".

prompt: Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't convince him.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "Mark" in this sentence. The pronoun "he" is a third-person singular pronoun, which is used to refer to a male subject. In this case, the subject of the sentence is "Sid", but the verb "explained" is in the passive voice, and "he" is used as the subject of the passive voice, referring back to the original subject "Sid". However, in this specific sentence, the context implies that "he" is actually referring to "Mark", the person who was not convinced by Sid's theory.

prompt: The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they advocated violence.  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "The demonstrators"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "they" in the sentence refers to "the demonstrators."   This is an example of a pronoun reference, where a pronoun (in this case, "they") is used to replace a noun (in this case, "the demonstrators"). The pronoun "they" is referring back to the subject of the sentence, which is the group that was refused a permit.

prompt: When Tommy dropped his ice cream, Timmy giggled, so father gave him a sympathetic look.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Timmy"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence above, "him" actually refers to "Tommy."   The reason is that the sentence is describing the action of "father giving a sympathetic look," and the object of that action is "him," which is implied to be the person who dropped the ice cream, which is "Tommy."

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Bill."   The reasoning behind this is based on the context and the pronoun's antecedent. "He" is used as a pronoun to refer back to a male subject, in this case, Bill. This is clear when we look at the previous sentences: "Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings" and "Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was." The use of "he" in these sentences directly refers to Bill.   In the sentence "I showed the master the flies... and he said that he should not go out to play for that week," "he" is used again, but this time it refers to "the master" because it is the subject that the sentence is describing, who is speaking and giving the punishment to Bill.

prompt: The journalists interviewed the stars of the new movie. They were very cooperative, so the interview lasted for a long time.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "The journalists"? Explain your choice.

In this sentence, "They" is a third-person plural pronoun, and it is used to refer to the subject of the sentence, which is "The journalists". This is an example of a pronoun that is used to avoid repetition of the noun and to improve the sentence's clarity and flow.  The reasoning behind this choice is that "The journalists" is a plural noun, and the pronoun "They" is also plural, which matches the grammatical number of the subject.

prompt: Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had given.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.

prompt: In the storm, the tree fell down and crashed through the roof of my house. Now, I have to get it repaired.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The roof"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to repeat it.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the lawyer"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. prompt: Since it was raining, I carried the newspaper over my backpack to keep it dry.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The newspaper"? Explain your choice.

prompt: If the con artist has succeeded in fooling Sam , he would have gotten a lot of money.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "The con artist"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The boy continued to whip the pony , and eventually the pony threw him over. John laughed out quite loud. "Served him right," he said.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "pony"? Explain your choice.

prompt: I put the cake away in the refrigerator . It has a lot of leftovers in it.  In the sentence above, does "It" refer to "The cake"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "It" in the sentence refers to "The cake." This is an example of a pronoun called a "reflexive pronoun," but more specifically, in this context, it's an example of an "indefinite pronoun" or a "generic pronoun."   However, a more accurate analysis would be that "it" is an example of a "noun substitute" or an "indefinite noun substitute" in this sentence, because "it" is used to refer back to a specific noun ("the cake") previously mentioned in the sentence.

prompt: The fish ate the worm . It was tasty.  In the sentence above, does "It" refer to "The worm"? Explain your choice.

This is an example of anaphora, where a pronoun is used to refer back to a noun that has already been mentioned in the sentence. In this case, the pronoun "It" is used to avoid repetition and make the sentence more concise.  So, to answer your question, "It" does not refer to "the worm", but rather to "the fish".

prompt: Babar wonders how he can get new clothing. Luckily, a very rich old man who has always been fond of little elephants understands right away that he is longing for a fine suit. prompt: So Mark slept. It was daylight when he woke with Warren 's hand upon his shoulder.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Warren"? Explain your choice.

So, the correct interpretation is that Mark woke up with his own hand on his shoulder, not Warren's hand on Mark's shoulder.

prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His hands"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Joe paid the detective after he delivered the final report on the case.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Joe"? Explain your choice.

prompt: As Andrea in the crop duster passed over Susan , she could see the landing strip.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Frank was upset with Tom because the toaster he had bought from him didn't work.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Tom"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Lily spoke to Donna , breaking her silence.  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "Donna"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The cat was lying by the mouse hole waiting for the mouse , but it was too cautious.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The cat"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Equally swoon-worthy is C.K. Dexter Haven , a pallid young dandy holding a jade-handled walking stick, with a poodle asleep at his feet  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Haven"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. prompt: The fish ate the worm . It was tasty.  In the sentence above, does "It" refer to "The fish"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "It" refers to "The fish."   This is an example of a pronoun called a "reflexive pronoun," which refers back to the subject of the sentence. The fish was tasty," but the original sentence implies that the fish enjoyed eating the worm, not that the fish itself was tasty.

prompt: Lionel is holding captive a scientist, Dr. Vardi , who has invented a device that turns animals invisible; Lionel plans to use it on Geoffrey and send him to steal nuclear material from an army vault.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Lionel"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "him" refers to "Geoffrey."   The pronoun "him" is a direct object pronoun, which is used to refer to a person or animal being acted upon by the verb. In this case, the verb "send" is acting on Geoffrey, and "him" is the direct object.

prompt: The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they feared violence.  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "The city councilmen"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they feared violence," "they" refers to "the city councilmen".   The pronoun "they" is used as a subject-verb agreement to refer back to "the city councilmen", who are performing the action of fearing violence. This is an example of a reflexive pronoun, where "they" is used to refer back to the same subject that performed the previous action, which in this case is "the city councilmen".

prompt: Frank felt vindicated when his longtime rival Bill revealed that he was the winner of the competition.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "Bill".   This is because the sentence is in a passive voice construction, specifically a passive construction where "Bill" is the subject of the verb "revealed", and the pronoun "he" is used as a pronoun to refer back to Bill after the verb. This is a common grammatical construction used to change the focus of the sentence from the doer of the action (Bill) to the person affected by the action (Frank).

prompt: Bob collapsed on the sidewalk. Soon he saw Carl coming to help. He was very concerned.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Bob".   The reason is that "He" is a pronoun used to refer back to a male noun that has been mentioned earlier in the sentence. In this case, "Bob" is the male noun that has been mentioned, and "He" is used to refer to him after he has collapsed on the sidewalk.

prompt: Dan took the rear seat while Bill claimed the front because his "Dibs!" was slow.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Susan knows all about Ann 's personal problems because she is nosy.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Pete envies Martin because he is very successful.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Pete"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share his toy.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Billy"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "his" refers to "Billy."   In this sentence, "his" is a possessive pronoun, which is used to show that the toy belongs to Billy. The word "his" is a masculine possessive pronoun, and it is used to indicate that the toy is owned by Billy, the male character in the sentence.

prompt: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "the bottle"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full," "it" refers to "the cup."   The reason for this is that the subject of the sentence is "I," and the action described is "I poured." The phrase "from the bottle into the cup" is a prepositional phrase that indicates the location and direction of the action, but it doesn't change the subject of the sentence. The verb "was" is in the predicate of the sentence, and its subject is "it," which must refer to the object of the action described by the verb "poured." Since "poured" is an action performed on "the cup," "it" logically refers to "the cup."

prompt: I used an old rag to clean the knife , and then I put it in the trash.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The knife"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "it" refers to "the knife". This is an example of anaphora, where a pronoun (in this case, "it") is used to refer back to a previously mentioned noun (the knife). This is a common grammatical technique used in English to avoid repetition and create more concise sentences. In this sentence, the pronoun "it" is used to refer to the knife that was cleaned and put in the trash, rather than repeating the word "knife" again.

prompt: John hired Bill to take care of him .  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "John hired Bill to take care of him," "him" is a pronoun that refers to John. This is because the verb "take care of" is a verb phrase that typically requires a direct object, and in this case, the direct object is the person or entity being taken care of, which is John. The sentence would not make sense if "him" referred to Bill, as Bill is the one doing the action of hiring, not being taken care of.

prompt: Jane knocked on the door, and Susan answered it. She invited her to come out.  In the sentence above, does "She" refer to "Jane"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, in this sentence, "She" refers to Susan.   The reason for this is that "She" is a pronoun that takes the subject of the sentence as its antecedent. In this case, the subject of the sentence is "Susan", and the pronoun "She" is used to refer back to that subject.   The sentence is structured as follows:  "Jane knocked on the door, and Susan answered it. She invited her to come out."  Here, the action of answering the door is attributed to Susan, and then the pronoun "She" is used to refer to Susan in the second part of the sentence.

prompt: The journalists interviewed the stars of the new movie. They were very persistent, so the interview lasted for a long time.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "The journalists"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, in the given sentence, "They" refers to "The journalists".   This is because "They" is a pronoun used as the subject of the sentence, agreeing with the plural noun "journalists" in number and gender. The sentence structure and word order also support this interpretation.

prompt: As Ollie carried Tommy up the long winding steps, his legs ached.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Ollie"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "his" refers to "Ollie". This is because the sentence is in the third person, referring to Ollie as the subject performing the action of carrying Tommy. The possessive pronoun "his" is used to describe Ollie's physical condition, indicating that Ollie is the one experiencing leg pain.

prompt: Carol believed that Rebecca regretted that she had stolen the watch.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Rebecca"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "she" refers to "Rebecca".   In the sentence, "she" is an anaphoric pronoun, which is a pronoun that refers back to a previously mentioned noun. In this case, "she" refers back to "Rebecca", the person who stole the watch.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education. He is very generous.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Charlie"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "He" refers to "Bob".   The reason for this is that "He" is the subject of the verb "is" in the sentence "He is very generous". This means that "He" is the one being described as generous, and that person is Bob, the one who paid for Charlie's college education.

prompt: All the buttons up the back of Dora 's plaid dress were buttoned outside-in. Maude should have thought to button her up; but no, she had left poor little Dora to do the best she could, alone.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Dora"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "she" does not refer to "Dora". The pronoun "she" is actually referring to "Maude".   This is because the sentence structure and context imply that Maude is the person who should have buttoned up Dora's dress, but failed to do so, leaving Dora to do it alone. Therefore, when the sentence mentions "she had left poor little Dora", the subject "she" logically refers to Maude, the person who was supposed to button up the dress but didn't.

prompt: The table was piled high with food , and on the floor beside it there were crocks, baskets, and a five-quart pail of milk.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "floor"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "it" does not refer to "floor".   The word "it" is a pronoun that is used as a reflexive pronoun, referring back to a noun or a phrase that has already been mentioned in the sentence. In this case, "it" is likely referring to the "table" that was "piled high with food".

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain , promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "his" does not refer to "Mark".   The phrase "Mr. Singer's heels" is a possessive phrase indicating that the heels belong to Mr. Singer. Then the phrase "his" in the sentence is a possessive pronoun referring back to Mr. Singer, meaning that the captain and his crew should stay in the cabin until the work is over.

prompt: The man lifted the boy onto his shoulders.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "The boy"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "his" does not refer to "the boy".   The pronoun "his" is a possessive pronoun, which indicates ownership or relationship. In this sentence, "his" is likely referring to "the man". This is because the sentence structure and context suggest that the man is lifting the boy onto his own shoulders.   For example, if "the boy" were the owner of the shoulders, the sentence would likely be "The boy lifted the girl onto his shoulders."

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Peter"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "the captain." The phrase "his food" implies that the food belongs to the captain, not Peter. This suggests that the speaker is speculating about the captain's illness and is considering the possibility that Peter may have bribed the cook to put something in the captain's food.

prompt: The signs over the shops' doors had pictures that indicated what work was done inside. Although more and more people were learning how to read, each artisan still had signs, not wishing to lose a possible patron merely because he happened to be illiterate.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "patron"? Explain your choice.
response: In the given sentence, "he" refers to the artisan.   The word "he" is a pronoun that takes the subject of the previous clause, which is "each artisan". The sentence structure is as follows: "each artisan... had signs... not wishing to lose a possible patron...". The word "he" is used in the subsequent clause "not wishing to lose a possible patron merely because he happened to be illiterate", replacing the word "artisan" as the subject.

prompt: Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't available.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "George"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "George". This is an example of a pronoun reference, where a pronoun is used to replace a noun in a sentence. In this case, the noun "George" is replaced by the pronoun "he". The pronoun "he" is a third-person singular masculine pronoun, which refers back to the male subject "George".

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one above it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "it" refers to "Sam's drawing." The word "it" is a pronoun that takes the place of a noun. In this case, "it" refers back to "Sam's drawing" because the sentence mentions that the drawing was hung just above Tina's and then states that it looked better with another one above it. This indicates that the subject of the sentence is Sam's drawing, and "it" is used to refer back to that subject.

prompt: The table won't fit through the doorway because it is too wide.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The table"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "it" refers to "The table."   This is an example of anaphora, a grammatical term referring to the use of a pronoun to refer back to a noun that has already been mentioned. In this case, the pronoun "it" is used to refer back to the noun "The table," which has already been mentioned in the sentence.

prompt: Emma Emma's mother had died long ago, and her education had been managed by an excellent woman as governess.  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "Emma's mother"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "her" refers to "Emma".   This is because the sentence structure suggests that Emma's mother had died long ago, and then Emma's education was managed by someone else. The phrase "her education" logically refers to Emma's education, not Emma's mother's education.

prompt: Bill passed the gameboy to John because his turn was next.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "John"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "his" refers to "John" in the sentence. This is because "his" is a possessive pronoun, which is used to show that something belongs to John. In this context, "his turn" indicates that John's turn is next, implying that the gameboy was passed from Bill to John because it was John's scheduled turn.

prompt: Of one thing Mark was sure. Harry knew much less than he did.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Harry"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to Mark.   This is because the pronoun "he" is used in the same sentence as the name "Mark", which suggests that "he" is a direct reference to Mark. Additionally, the phrase "Of one thing Mark was sure" establishes Mark as the subject of the sentence, making it clear that "he" refers to Mark.

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "the captain"? Explain your choice.
response: In the given sentence, "his" refers to "the captain." The reason for this is that "his" is a possessive pronoun used to indicate that the noun (in this case, the captain) is the owner of something (the food). Since the sentence mentions "the captain's illness," it implies that the food is related to the captain, so "his" is used to show that the food belongs to the captain.

prompt: What about the time you cut up tulip bulbs in the hamburgers because you thought they were onions?  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "hamburgers"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "they" refers to "tulip bulbs." This is because "they" is a pronoun used to refer back to a previously mentioned noun, in this case, "tulip bulbs."

prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His eyes"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "them" in the sentence refers to "his eyes".   The word "them" is a pronoun, and in this context, it's an object pronoun, referring to the subject "his eyes". This is an example of a pronoun referring to a noun in a different grammatical case.   In this case, the subject of the sentence is "Fred covered his eyes", so "his eyes" is the noun phrase being referred to by the pronoun "them" when it appears later in the sentence.

prompt: Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't understand him.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Sid"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "Sid". This is because "he" is the subject of the sentence, and the subject of the sentence is the one performing the action (in this case, explaining). Since Sid is the one explaining his theory, "he" is a pronoun referring back to Sid.

prompt: Tom gave Ralph a lift to school so he wouldn't have to drive alone.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Ralph"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Tom".   This is because "he" is the subject of the verb "gave", which is in the same clause as "Tom". The phrase "Ralph" is the indirect object, indicating the person receiving the action, but the subject of the sentence is "Tom", so "he" must refer to Tom.

prompt: When my parents died, I was not earning enough to keep myself or my crippled sister Nelly , and without our kind mistress , we would have gone to the poorhouse. Nelly calls her her angel and she has good right to do so. her  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "mistress"? Explain your choice.
response: In the given sentence, "her" refers to "Nelly."   This is because the sentence structure is "her (Nelly's) angel," which implies that Nelly has the right to call the mistress her angel. The phrase "her" is a possessive pronoun indicating that the angel belongs to Nelly.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week," "he" does not refer to "the master."   This is because the subject of the first clause is "he did not give him any more punishment of that kind," and "he" refers back to "Bill." This is an example of a pronoun reference that is a subject-verb agreement.  The second instance of "he" is a separate pronoun that refers to the master, as indicated by the context of the sentence.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "him" refers to Bill.   The reason is that the subject-verb agreement and the context of the sentence indicate that the action is directed at Bill. The sentence "he did not give him any more punishment of that kind" suggests that the subject "he" is the master, and the object of the action "him" is Bill. The master is the one giving the punishment to Bill.

prompt: Ann asked Mary what time the library closes, because she had forgotten.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Mary"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "she" refers to "Mary". This is because "she" is the subject of the sentence, and it is used to refer to the person who was asked by Ann. The verb "had forgotten" also agrees with "she", indicating that "she" is the subject of the sentence. In this context, "she" is a pronoun that takes the place of Mary's name, making the sentence easier to read and understand.
